<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q71')" data-correct-answer="E">
<strong style="display: block;">According to Modigliani and Miller Proposition II (no taxes), what is the main implication of increasing financial leverage for a firm’s equity holders?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q71" value="A"> A. The firm’s overall cost of capital increases with leverage.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q71" value="B"> B. The cost of equity decreases because debt is cheaper financing.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q71" value="C"> C. The risk of equity decreases as leverage increases.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q71" value="D"> D. The firm’s value declines due to higher bankruptcy risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q71" value="E"> E. The cost of equity rises linearly with leverage because shareholders bear more financial risk.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q71" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: E. Under MM Proposition II (no taxes), the expected return on equity increases with leverage as shareholders take on more risk.  
Although $r_E$ rises, the overall cost of capital ($r_U$) remains constant in perfect markets.
</div>
